channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: New York City finally joins London, Singapore and other world-class cities with a tap-only subway system
item.description: The Metrocard replaced the subway token in 1994, but now it's being phased out for tap-and-go, first introduced in 2019.

item.title: Four Takeaways From the New York Times Profile of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: The congresswoman discussed her break with President Trump and her journey from MAGA zealot to political isolation.

item.title: In Trump’s D.C. Crackdown, Murder Victims’ Families Say He’s Ignoring Them
item.description: President Trump insists there are no more murders in Washington, D.C. “I wish that was true,” said Jamia Vaden, whose sister was gunned down in Novemb...

item.title: Why We Keep Falling for Narcissistic Leaders
Parts of New York and New England Brace for Ice Storm
item.description: Several states were under weather warnings or advisories after the same winter storm battered the Midwest over the weekend. Tens of thousands of power...

item.title: African millennials and Gen Z are quitting their big-city dreams to go make more money back on the farm
item.description: “A lot of my friends who graduated at the same time as me now work as motorcycle taxi drivers and barely make a living,” says 33-year-old Filly Mangas...

item.title: Gen Z could wave goodbye to résumés because most companies have turned to skills-based recruitment—and find it more effective, research shows
item.description: It might not be long until résumé are a thing of the past because most bosses are favoring skills-based hiring and reporting big results.

item.title: The weakest labor market since 2011 has BofA asking, ‘Dude, where’s my job?’
item.description: "A lack of recovery in the jobs market and a slower U.S. economy are key risks to watch for 2026."

item.title: How Kevin Hassett Became a Trump Loyalist and Fed Chair Contender

item.title: Every year, a billionaire CEO doles out $1,000 checks to local college grads—with a catch: They have to give half the money to charity
item.description: “The turmoil in our country has increased the need for caring, sharing and compassion,” Rob Hale said.

item.title: For Zelensky, Just Keeping Trump Talking About Ukraine Peace Deal Counts as a Win
